prompt: Is your living situation covered by the Residential Tenancy Act?
Is your living situation covered by the Residential Tenancy Act?
Is your living situation covered by the Residential Tenancy Act?
assist: Lots of housing situations are not covered by B.C's laws - these include most kinds of temporary situations where you dont have a lease, "transitional housing" , and situations where you share a kitchen or bathroom with the Landlord. See: http://tenants.bc.ca/am-i-covered-by-the-law/

prompt: Use the following resource to determine if you are covered by the Residential Tenancy Act.
choice: TRAC: Am I Covered by the RTA

prompt: If you are not covered by the RTA you will find it hard (but not impossible) to fight back.
notes: Not sure where this should link to

prompt: Have you received a written eviction notice?
Have you received a written eviction notice?
assist: Your landlord is required by law to issue you a written eviction notice. Without written notice you eviction is not lawful. Please keep all copies of correspondances with your landlord and try and have a witness present whenever you interact with your landlord

prompt: Has your landlord tried to change your locks, threaten you, or harass you in any way?
choice: Yes, I need to speak with an advocate right away!
assist: If you are being harassed by the landlord you need to speak with an advocate as soon as possible!

prompt: Has your landlord tried to change your locks, threaten you, or harass you in any way?
choice: No, but I think my landlord wants to evict me.

prompt: Was it on the proper form?
assist: Your landlord should use the proper form (http://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/housing-tenancy/residential-tenancies/ending-a-tenancy/landlord-notice)

prompt: Was it on the proper form?
Your notice is likely not lawful. Take some time to learn about your rights.
assist: Take some steps to protect yourself

prompt: Your notice is likely not lawful. Take some time to learn about your rights.
choice: Next Step: Write a Letter to Your Landlord
assist: You can write your landlord a letter explaining why what they did was unlawful. This is an opportunity to de-escalate and negotiate around the eviction

prompt: Your notice is likely not lawful. Take some time to learn about your rights.
What was the reason for your eviction?
choice: I did not pay my rent or utilities in full and on time
assist: Your landlord is saying that you did not pay rent, or that you were late to pay rent, or something along those lines

prompt: What was the reason for your eviction?
choice: The eviction is related to something I am alleged to have done (i.e issues with noise, guests, etc)
assist: Landlord's should give 30 days notice for evictions that are not rent related or 'no cause' evictions related to renovations.

prompt: What was the reason for your eviction?
choice: I am being evicted for 'no fault'
assist: This would include renovations, the landlord's family moving in, or building demolition

prompt: What was the reason for your eviction?

prompt: Were you given 10 Days Notice to Move Out?
Were you given 10 Days Notice to Move Out?
Have more than 5 days passed since you received your eviction notice?
assist: If you do not pay your rent back within 5 days of receiving an eviction notice for unpaid rent you can be legally evicted

prompt: Have more than 5 days passed since you received your eviction notice?
Are you able to pay your rent in full within 5 days of receiving this notice?
choice: Yes, I should pay my landlord immediately.
assist: If you pay your landlord before 5 days pass you cannot be legally evicted

prompt: Are you able to pay your rent in full within 5 days of receiving this notice?

prompt: Were you given 30 Days Notice?
Were you given 30 Days Notice?
assist: Your landlord must give you 30 days notice of an eviction. If they do not you do not have to move out.

prompt: Have more than 10 days passed since you received notice?
Have more than 10 days passed since you received notice?

prompt: Did your landlord indicate what specifically you did wrong?
assist: Your landlord should indicate on the form what precisely you are being evicted for

prompt: Did your landlord indicate what specifically you did wrong?
assist: Your landlord should indicate why they are evicting you. A reason for eviction should be written on the notice to end tenancy.

prompt: Did your landlord ever give you a formal warning?
assist: if your landlord gave you a written warning you will have to dispute the substance of your landlord's allegations

prompt: Do you have evidence that the reason your landlord gave for your eviction is misleading or untrue?
